awd_titl_txt: S&AS: INT: COLLAB: Composable and Verifiable Design for Autonomous Humanoid Robots in Space Missions
awd_abstract_narration:
Future space missions will increasingly rely on autonomous robots like the NASA Valkyrie human-centered robot for deploying equipment, assisting astronauts, and maintaining facilities in real world partially-observable and cluttered environments. Despite significant progress in robotic mobility, manipulation, and perception, there has been relatively little progress on providing formal performance guarantees for these integrated systems. Formal guarantees are critical for achieving long term autonomy, particularly for robots performing complex tasks requiring  successful execution of multiple component subtasks. Thus, the goal of this project is to develop performance guarantees for space robots operating in unstructured real world environments. Although robots are used as design examples, the project is of a basic research nature and the results can have impacts on other fields, such as sensor/actuator networks, manufacturing and transportation systems. The multidisciplinary approach taken for this project will help broaden participation of underrepresented groups and positively impact engineering and computer science education.

The objective of this project is to develop new methods to synthesize coordinated manipulation and locomotion plans and control policies that verifiably adhere to formal mission specifications. There are two major thrusts. First, the PIs plan to develop manipulation, locomotion, and motion primitives that can provide performance guarantees in unstructured, partially observable, and dynamic environments. The focus will be on using methods from perception and planning under uncertainty to provide guarantees in cluttered and partially observable environments. The PIs will also leverage new tools from hybrid systems and sampling based methods to achieve controllers with verifiable guarantees through contact mode switches. Second, the PIs plan to devise methods to automatically synthesize mission plans in a way that can guarantee the accomplishment of high-level mission goals or bound the probability of failure. The focus will be on automatic and learning-based design, enabling the system to adapt to changing environments, uncertain faults and potential adversaries. Most of the work performed under this project will be demonstrated in the context of complex space tasks inspired by NASA scenarios.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
In “An efficient and direct method for trajectory optimization of robots constrained by contact kinematics and forces” published in Springer’s Autonomous Robots in 2021, UT Austin devises rigorous methods to obtain optimal trajectories of legged robots under contact constraints. In “MPC-Based Hierarchical Task Space Control of Underactuated and Constrained Robots for Execution of Multiple Tasks” published in the proceedings of the IEEE Conference in Decision and Control in 2020, UT Austin describes a model-predictive control method by which humanoid robots can track multiple task trajectories simultaneously with higher accuracy than conventional feedback control methods. In “Online Gain Adaptation for Whole-Body Control of Legged Robots with Unknown Disturbances” published in Frontiers in Robotics and AI in 2021, UT Austin devises adaptive control methods for humanoid robots such that they can adapt to continuous or intermittent contact disturbances such as those encountered when moving around humans. In addition to these core publications, UT Austin has leveraged this project with other federally funded projects to achieve unique capabilities. In “​​Dynamic Locomotion For Passive-Ankle Biped Robots And Humanoids Using Whole-Body Locomotion Control” published in the International Journal of Robotics Research in 2020, UT Austin reports the achievement of one of the first unsupported line-feet dynamic walking capabilities in a bipedal robot. And in “Versatile Locomotion Planning and Control for Humanoid Robots” published in Frontiers in Robotics and AI in 2021, UT Austin devises a control middleware that integrates trajectory generation and whole-body control for a variety of humanoid robots. Finally UT Austin has deployed control algorithms in NASA’s Valkyrie humanoid robot to perform complex legged manipulation behaviors and mitigate thermal buildup. 


The key outcomes of the project by the Notre Dame University team include a set of formal methods to enable automatic synthesis of reactive mission plans that can guarantee the accomplishment of high-level mission goals in the face of uncertainties. Although much progress has been made through controller synthesis from temporal logic specifications, existing approaches generally require conservative assumptions and do not scale well with system dimensionality. We therefore focused on the scalability issues of formal design and proposed a scalable, provably complete algorithm that synthesizes continuous trajectories for IPS to satisfy complex missions given as temporal logic specifications. To achieve scalability (with respect to the size of specifications and planning horizon), we have harnessed highly efficient Boolean satisfiability (SAT) and Linear Programming (LP) solvers to find trajectories that satisfy non-convex Signal Temporal Logic (STL) specifications. The design methods were extended to hybrid systems with respect to temporal logic specifications, since many IPS exhibit a hybrid dynamic nature. We further extend the formal design approach when IPS need to act with imperfect information about the environment by employing a counterexample-guided-inductive-synthesis approach for control from probabilistic signal temporal logic (PrSTL) specifications. The proposed design algorithms are proven sound and complete. Furthermore, the formal design methods are implemented as a Python toolbox. The results from this project could significantly advance approaches for the next generation intelligent humanoid robotics systems performing high-level missions in a verifiable manner in space environments. 


The focus of the effort at Northeastern University has been to devise manipulation primitives that can be sequenced to create complex composite behaviors. Specifically, the Northeastern effort has been to: 1) devise grasp primitives with verifiable performance; 2) devise manipulation primitives; 3) devise perceptual capabilities that can inform decision making; 4) devise methods for sequencing manipulation primitives. With regard to the first effort (grasp primitives), the Northeastern group continued their work on grasp detection, resulting in several publications including "Grasp pose detection in point clouds", published in the International Journal of Robotics Research in 2017 and "Efficient and Accurate Candidate Generation for Grasp Pose Detection in SE(3)", published in the IEEE Int'l Conf. on Robotics and Automation in 2021. Regarding the second effort (manipulation primitives), the Northeastern group made significant progress on methods involving reinforcement learning in conjunction with spatial action spaces to learn a variety of complex manipulation behaviors including arrangement and palletization tasks, tasks related to the administration of COVID tests, and drawer opening tasks. This work was published in multiple venues including "Equivariant  Learning in Spatial Action Spaces" at the Conference on Robotic Learning in 2021. With regard to the third effort (perceptual capabilities) and the fourth effort (sequencing manipulation primitives), the work at Northeastern focused on approaches that frame the problem as a Markov decision process. In "Learning discrete state abstractions with deep variational inference" published at the 3rd Symposium on Advances in Approximate Bayesian Inference in 2020, the Northeastern group explored methods of automatically discovering task-appropriate abstractions that could be used to define task primitives. This was an extension of our prior work "Online abstraction with MDP homomorphisms for deep learning", published at the Int'l Conf. on Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems in 2019.

 


Last Modified: 04/01/2022
Modified by: Robert Platt

In "MPC-Based Hierarchical Task Space Control of Underactuated and Constrained Robots for Execution of Multiple Tasks" published in the proceedings of the IEEE Conference in Decision and Control in 2020, UT Austin describes a model-predictive control method by which humanoid robots can track multiple task trajectories simultaneously with higher accuracy than conventional feedback control methods. In addition to these core publications, UT Austin has leveraged this project with other federally funded projects to achieve unique capabilities.
